'''Roald Dahl''' (13 September 1916 â 23 November 1990) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[novel]]ist, [[short story]] [[writer]] and [[screenwriter]], born in [[Wales]] of [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] parents. After service in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War, In which he became a [[flying ace]], he rose to prominence in the 1940s with works for both [[Children's literature|children]] and adults, and became one of the world's bestselling authors. His short stories are known for their unexpected endings, and his children's books for their unsentimental, often very [[dark humour]]. Some of his most popular books include ''[[The Twits]]'', ''[[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]]'', ''[[James and the Giant Peach]]'', ''[[Matilda (novel)|Matilda]]'', ''[[The Witches (book)|The Witches]]'' and ''[[The BFG]]''.
+
'''Roald Dahl''' (13 September 1916 â 23 November 1990) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[novel]]ist, [[short story]] [[writer]] and [[screenwriter]], born in [[Wales]] of [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] parents. After service in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War, in which he became a [[flying ace]], he rose to prominence in the 1940s with works for both [[Children's literature|children]] and adults, and became one of the world's bestselling authors. His short stories are known for their unexpected endings, and his children's books for their unsentimental, often very [[dark humour]]. Some of his most popular books include ''[[The Twits]]'', ''[[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]]'', ''[[James and the Giant Peach]]'', ''[[Matilda (novel)|Matilda]]'', ''[[The Witches (book)|The Witches]]'' and ''[[The BFG]]''.
